name: 3-bromo-2,4,6-trimethylaniline
Reason: To predict the melting point of 3-bromo-2,4,6-trimethylaniline, we start with aniline which serves as our basic unit. Aniline has a melting point of around -6 degrees Celsius. Each substituent present on the aniline ring will influence the melting point. The methyl groups (electron-donating by inductive effect) when attached to an aromatic ring slightly increase its electron density, could also lead to an increase in intermolecular interactions such as van der Waals forces, raising the melting point. Each methyl group might add approximately 5 degrees Celsius. The presence of the bromine atom (a fairly heavy halogen), capable of facilitating stronger dispersive forces due to its larger electron cloud, might raise the melting point significantly more than a methyl group. We can estimate its contribution to be around 20 degrees Celsius due to the increase in molecular weight and polarizability. The amino group (NH2) could form intermolecular hydrogen bonds which generally leads to a substantial increase in the melting point; however, in this case, it is on the aromatic ring which could reduce hydrogen bonding due to delocalization of the lone pair into the pi-system, reducing its impact. We might estimate the hydrogen bonding contribution of the amino group to be around +10 degrees Celsius considering the hindrance on bonding.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit for comparison is aniline, which has a melting point of -6 degrees Celsius. The introduction of a bromine atom typically increases the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the introduction of a polarizable electron, which can lead to stronger intermolecular forces such as dipole-dipole interactions. This effect can be estimated to increase the melting point by approximately 40 degrees Celsius. Each methyl group attached to the aniline increases the molecular weight and provides some steric hindrance, which can slightly raise the melting point. However, the effect of each methyl group is relatively small, so we can estimate an increase of about 5 degrees Celsius per methyl group. With three methyl groups, this would be an increase of 15 degrees Celsius. Therefore, the predicted melting point would be the sum of the effects of the bromine and methyl groups.
##Prediction: 41.0
